name: Burden of Proof
definition: The burden of proof is to be beyond a reasonable doubt in criminal cases and a preponderance of the evidence in civil cases.

name: Citizen’s Arrests
definition: All citizens of San Andreas are legally empowered to conduct a citizen's arrest when they witness a crime, there is risk to public safety, and they contact law enforcement.

name: Statute of Limitations
definition: 30 days for most civil and criminal charges. 14 days for appeals. Warrants are five days and do not extend statute of limitations.

name: BOLO
definition: A BOLO provides reasonable suspicion for a stop. The trooper can invite the individual to attend a police station for questioning, and offer a lawyer. The individual may decline. A DA may then seek an Injunction to Appear.

name: Injunction to Appear
definition: A court order, signed by a judge, that compels an individual to appear at a police station to listen to questions.

name: Brady Violation
definition: Occurs when a prosecutor fails to provide a defendant with evidence that is favorable to their case. This is a violation of the defendant's constitutional rights.

name: Exigent Circumstances
definition:
Emergency Situations: If police hear indications of violence coming from a residence, they may enter without a warrant to ensure the safety of those inside.,
Imminent Destruction of Evidence: If police have reason to believe that evidence of a crime is about to be destroyed, they may enter a residence without a warrant to seize it.,
Hot Pursuit: If police are pursuing a suspect who enters a residence, they may enter without a warrant to apprehend the suspect.

name: Affirmative Defense
definition: A legal strategy where the defendant admits to the facts of the case but argues that there are reasons why they should not be held liable/found guilty, even if those facts are proven. This shifts the burden of proof to the defendant to prove the affirmative defense. Common affirmative defenses include self-defense, duress, entrapment, and statute of limitations.

name: Reasonable Suspicion
definition: When an officer has reason to believe someone might be involved in or have committed a crime. Allows officers to detain, investigate further, and ask questions. It’s not enough to arrest someone. Based on training and experience.

name: Probable Cause
definition: The logical belief that a crime has been committed, supported by facts and evidence.
